required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 08, 2015
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Treatment of Acne Scarring With a Novel Procedure Combination
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Subcision and Calcium Hydroxylapatite (Radiesse) Injection on Rolling Acne Scarring Appearance

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to look at the efficacy of subdermal manipulation and filler injection in the improvement of acne scar appearance.

detailed_description.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to determine whether the use of subcision in conjunction with calcium hydroxylapatite injections will improve the appearance of rolling acne scars better than subcision alone.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

arm_group.description: scars receive subdermal manipulation AND injection of a filler

intervention.intervention_name: subdermal manipulation AND injection of a filler
intervention.description: scars receive subdermal manipulation AND injection of a filler

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18 and over
- Have two acne scar areas
- The subjects are in good health
- The subject has the willingness and the ability to understand and provide informed consent for the use of their tissue and communicate with the investigator.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Under 18 years of age
- Pregnancy or Lactation
- Subjects who are unable to understand the protocol or to give informed consent
- Subjects with mental illness

facility.name: Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Department of Dermatology

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor in Dermatology, Otolaryngology- Head and Neck Surgery, and Surgery-Organ Transplantation
